;俄罗斯间谍正在利用黑客攻击乌克兰执法机构的计算机系统，以识别并获取相关证据乌克兰网络防御负责人周五对路透社表示，俄罗斯涉嫌战争罪。

;

;黑客在俄罗斯外国、国内和军事情报机构工作，加强了针对乌克兰总检察长办公室和部门的数字入侵活动。乌克兰国家特殊通信和信息保护局 (SSSCIP) 负责人尤里·什奇霍尔 (Yurii Shchyhol) 表示，该局负责记录战争罪行。该局负责处理陷入困境的国家的网络防御。

;

;“方向发生了变化，从Shchyhol 表示，“这种针对法院、检察官和执法单位的转变表明，黑客正在收集有关能源设施的证据，而这在以前并不经常成为目标。”他补充说，“俄罗斯在乌克兰的战争罪行”，以跟踪乌克兰的调查。

;

;间谍活动将在即将于周一发布的 SSSCIP 报告中被标记。

;

;路透社查看了该报告的副本，报告称黑客还试图收集有关在乌克兰被捕的俄罗斯国民的情报，以“帮助这些人避免起诉并将他们带回俄罗斯”。

;<什奇霍尔说：“我们确定参与这项活动的组织是俄罗斯 GRU 和 FSB 情报机构的一部分。”

;

;俄罗斯外交部和联邦安全局 (FSB) 没有立即采取行动。回应路透社的书面评论请求。无法联系到俄罗斯格鲁乌军事情报机构置评。

;

;Shchyhol 以安全问题为由，拒绝透露具体哪些单位是黑客活动的目标。他补充说，与 2022 年下半年相比，SSSCIP 记录的网络安全事件数量在今年前六个月增长了 123%。

;

;俄罗斯黑客优先针对政府机构，并试图获取利益。施奇霍尔说，他们的电子邮件服务器的访问权限，但没有详细说明。路透社无法独立核实 Shchyhol 和报告中详细描述的任何黑客行为。

;

;周二，总部位于荷兰的国际刑事法院 (ICC) 表示 ;上周末在其计算机网络上检测到“异常活动;”。周五仍不清楚幕后黑手是谁

;

;法院在三月份成为头条新闻，当时 ;因涉嫌从乌克兰非法驱逐儿童而对俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京发出逮捕令;。克里姆林宫否认这些指控和法院的管辖权。

;

;在俄罗斯入侵之前2022 年 2 月，西方情报机构警告称，潜在的网络攻击可能会蔓延到其他地方，并对全球计算机网络造成“溢出”损害。

;

;虽然迄今为止几乎没有证据表明存在溢出效应，但黑客攻击已定期发生。俄罗斯在其军事行动中利用了这一点。

;

;一个名为“Sandworm”的俄罗斯情报黑客组织试图;对乌克兰电网发动破坏性网络攻击;于 2022 年 4 月被挫败。

;

;Shchyhol 表示，他的部门看到了证据表明俄罗斯黑客正在访问乌克兰境内的私人安全摄像头，以监控远程导弹和无人机袭击的结果。

;

;“我们记录了多次试图访问受攻击设施附近的摄像机以及提供信息的系统的尝试俄罗斯去年冬季空袭乌克兰能源基础设施，导致数百万人全面断电。什奇霍尔表示，能源基础设施也成为网络攻击的目标，他预计这些攻击将在今年冬天再次发生。

;

;“你需要明白，即使乌克兰在战场上获胜，网络战争也不会结束。” Shchyhol 说道。

;如果乔·拜登接受美国汽车工人联合会的邀请，参观他们的纠察线，美国总统将表示支持一位总统历史学家表示，工会工人卷入劳资纠纷，这是美国一个多世纪以来从未发生过的情况。

;

;美国汽车工人联合会周五邀请拜登探访纠察线上的工人，并;表示将扩大;底特律通用汽车美国各地零部件配送中心举行罢工 ;(GM.N); 和克莱斯勒母公司 Stellantis ;(STLAM.MI);。该公司表示，与福特汽车的谈判取得了实际进展;(FN);。;

;白宫尚未对这一邀请发表评论。许多工会已经支持拜登连任，但美国汽车工人联合会目前暂不支持。 ;拜登表示汽车制造商应该“走得更远”; 确保创纪录的企业利润意味着 UAW 的创纪录合同，”这与工会领导人的观点相呼应。

;

;联邦政策决策对底特律三巨头和 UAW 都有很大的利害关系。汽车制造商指望华盛顿为电动汽车生产提供数十亿美元的补贴。他们正在与拜登政府就未来的排放规则进行谈判，这些规则要求转向电动汽车，业界认为电动汽车的速度太快且成本太高。

;

;与此同时，工会，担心向电动汽车的过渡将意味着失业，因为这些车辆在生产时需要的零部件较少。

;

;前总统唐纳德·特朗普可能是拜登在 2024 年竞选中的对手，他计划;下周前往底特律;在集会上发言为汽车工人做广告，试图赢回一些在 2020 年战胜特朗普时投奔拜登的蓝领工人。特朗普呼吁普通工会工人无视他们的领导人。

;

;特朗普尚未表示他是否会前往纠察线。美国汽车工人联合会主席肖恩·费恩在本周早些时候抨击了特朗普，称该工会正在“与亿万富翁阶级以及以牺牲工人为代价来让唐纳德·特朗普这样的人致富的经济作斗争。”

;

;最后一位美国总统苏里说，对罢工工人的这种支持可能是西奥多·罗斯福。 1902 年，罗斯福邀请罢工的煤炭工人与政府官员和管理人员一起到白宫，担心该国面临煤炭短缺。

;

;在这次打破先例的会议之前，罗斯福和拜登一样，发现自己与;谈判筹码很少;。

;

;根据 ;劳工部网站上的罢工叙述;。 “我不知道如何继续。”

;

;纠察线上的工人对于拜登是否应该访问的感受很复杂。一些人表示政界人士应该置身事外，而另一些人则表示，如果罢工继续下去，他们将欢迎支持。

;

;“就我个人而言，如果拜登挺身而出并表现出一些支持，我不会介意，”说周二，俄亥俄州托莱多市 55 岁的劳拉·齐林斯基 (Laura Zielinski) 注意到拜登在 2010 年担任副总统期间访问了 Stellantis Toledo 装配厂。

;

;“这样的支持将使谈判成为焦点 -有点对公司有推动作用。”

;美国汽车工人联合会扩大了其;针对底特律汽车制造商的罢工;通用汽车;(GM.N); 和克莱斯勒母公司 Stellantis ;(STLAM.MI);，但保留了福特;(FN); 工会周五表示，由于谈判取得进展，罢工仅限于一家工厂。

;

;汽车工人工会于美国东部时间周五中午（格林威治标准时间 1600 点）开始罢工，反对 38 名;通用汽车和 Stellantis 遍布美国的零部件配送中心; ，扩大了前所未有的同步罢工，;分别从一家装配厂开始底特律三巨头的;。新增设施使已经罢工的 12,700 名工人增加了约 5,600 名。

;

;;UAW 主席 Shawn Fain; 在 Facebook 直播活动中表示，通过定向分发，该活动有超过 50,000 人观看，YouTube 上还有近 10,000 人观看使罢工成为全国性的活动。

;

;他向穿着军装风格迷彩衬衫的工会成员发表讲话，身后标语写着“创纪录的利润，创纪录的合同”等信息。

;

;该公告由工会精心管理，让汽车制造商猜测接下来可能会袭击哪些设施。许多分析师认为下一个目标将是生产公司最赚钱的车辆的工厂。

;

;相反，费恩表示，扩大罢工的决定将影响试图获得维修零件的消费者。 “从加利福尼亚州到马萨诸塞州，从俄勒冈州到佛罗里达州，我们将遍布各地。”

;

;“Stellantis 和通用汽车尤其需要大力推动，”他说。

;

;费恩说。他们在福特还有更多工作要做，但“我们确实希望认识到福特正在表明他们认真对待达成协议。”

;

;他还威胁要在他的 Stellantis 关键零部件工厂采取更多行动。家乡印第安纳州科科莫。 Stellantis 在科科莫拥有四家工厂，生产广泛应用于该汽车制造商产品线的发动机和变速箱。

;

;Stellantis 表示希望能够整合并关闭部分零部件配送中心。

;< p>;费恩邀请;乔·拜登总统;与其他政客、朋友和家人一起参加纠察线。总统一直直言不讳地支持工会要求;更好的工资和;。

;

;正在寻求新任期的前总统唐纳德·特朗普将于下周在密歇根州向汽车工人就罢工问题发表讲话。

;

;费恩表示，福特已经改善了合同报价，包括提高利润分享和同意让工人因工厂关闭而罢工，但表示工会与福特之间仍存在“严重问题”。

;

;福特还同意在至少 90 天的时间内转换临时员工他说，交易批准后将聘用为全职员工。

;

;通用汽车没有立即发表评论。 Stellantis 表示，该公司正在继续与工会会面。

;

;福特表示，正在继续进行谈判，并补充说“在达成协议之前，我们还有更多工作要做。”

;< p>;9 月 15 日，近 13,000 名 UAW 工人在密苏里州、密歇根州和俄亥俄州的工厂举行罢工。这些工厂生产福特野马、吉普牧马人和雪佛兰科罗拉多，以及其他受欢迎的车型。

;

;Wedbush 分析师 Daniel Ives 表示UAW 的这一最新举措标志着与汽车制造商的谈判出现了分歧。

;

;“当前的交易对底特律 3 的商业模式来说是一个鱼雷，”他说。 “仅仅为了避免罢工而达成协议并完成它，在接下来的 24 小时内是很棒的，但在接下来的 30 年里却是一场噩梦。就分而治之而言，这就像工会 101 一样。”

;

; AutoForecast Solutions 全球汽车预测副总裁 Sam Fiorani 表示，福特的家族控制结构使其关注点与其他两家不同。

;

;“通用汽车和 Stellantis 正在考虑股东价值，而福特正在考虑股东价值。从长远来看，他们必须与劳工交朋友。”

;

;这场僵局加剧了人们对长期罢工行动的担忧，这可能会扰乱生产并削弱美国经济增长。周四发布的;路透社/益普索民意调查;显示，美国人支持罢工的汽车工人。

;

;此次罢工已成为拜登和想要取代他的共和党候选人关注的焦点。鉴于工会尚未支持拜登参加下届总统选举，UAW 对拜登的邀请是一个值得注意的提议。

;

;白宫周五拒绝发表评论。

;

;费恩表示底特律汽车制造商在让高管和投资者致富的同时，还没有与工人分享足够的利润。

;

;通用汽车总裁马克·罗伊斯 (Mark Reuss) 本周驳斥了这些说法，称目前向工会提出的提议将是慷慨的，而且公司的利润已经重新投资于向电动汽车的过渡。

;

;汽车制造商提议在 4-1/2 年内加薪 20%，而 UAW 则寻求 40%。

;

;工会还希望消除新老员工以及某些零部件工厂和装配厂工人之间的工资差距。费恩周五表示，工会已就取消福特和通用汽车部分零部件工厂的较低工资水平进行了谈判。 Fain 表示，但 Stellantis 尚未同意提高其 MOPAR 零部件业务的工资。

;

;福特在最后一刻达成了一项协议，以避免其;周二晚些时候加拿大运营;。代表约 5,600 名加拿大汽车工人的 Unifor 一直威胁要在该国所有三个福特工厂举行罢工。

;

;随着罗恩·德桑蒂斯 (Ron DeSantis) 获得共和党总统提名的道路似乎越来越窄，佛罗里达州州长决定全力以赴也许他最具争议性和潜在毒性的政策立场是：支持为期六周的堕胎禁令。

;

;在堕胎问题上的强硬立场充满了政治风险。民意调查显示，;大多数;美国人赞成在怀孕早期进行该手术，一些主要捐赠者是;担心;德桑蒂斯的观点会降低他明年获得温和选民支持的机会。

;

;但德桑蒂斯似乎认为这个问题可能是他得分的最佳希望2024 年竞选的首场提名竞赛将于 1 月在爱荷华州举行，该州出人意料地取得了胜利。德桑蒂斯竞选团队认为，在爱荷华州获胜可能会迫使其他候选人退出竞选，使他成为选民当前最受欢迎的前总统唐纳德·特朗普的主要替代者。

;

;最近几天，德桑蒂斯的竞选团队强调了今年佛罗里达州和爱荷华州通过了为期六周的堕胎禁令，同时试图与特朗普形成鲜明对比，特朗普在接受 NBC 新闻采访时称德桑蒂斯签署此类限制性措施的决定是“一件可怕的事情和一个可怕的错误”。 /p>;

;特朗普还警告共和党内的堕胎反对者，如果把这个问题推得太远，明年将会产生政治后果，并建议作为总统，他将努力与堕胎权利运动找到一些共同点。

;

; p>;

;他的言论激怒了一些福音派领袖，并为德桑蒂斯和他的竞选团队迅速利用了一个机会，因为他们认为不能相信特朗普会在这个问题上保持保守路线。

;

;“如果（特朗普）说他会让民主党在生命权方面感到满意，我认为所有反堕胎者都应该知道他正准备出卖你们，”德桑蒂斯在爱荷华州接受电台采访时说道。周。

;

;X（该网站以前称为 Twitter）上的德桑蒂斯作战室帐户重播了 NBC 特朗普的采访，并以爱荷华州牧师批评特朗普为特色。

;;Azerbaijan envisages an amnesty for ethnic Armenian fighters who give up their arms, Hikmet Hajiyev, foreign policy adviser to Azerbaijan's president, told Reuters in a television interview, after Azeri forces took over the enclave of Karabakh this week.;
;;
;;Law enforcement officers stand guard outside the government building during a rally to demand the resignation of Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan following Nagorno-Karabakh surrender, in Yerevan, Armenia, September 21, 2023. Hayk Baghdasaryan/Photolure via REUTERS/file photo;
;

;The ethnic Armenian leadership of breakaway Nagorno-Karabakh said on Friday that there was no agreement yet with Azerbaijan on security guarantees or an amnesty after a lightning Azeri offensive forced them into a humiliating ceasefire deal.

;

;The future of Karabakh and its 120,000 ethnic Armenians hangs in the balance: Azerbaijan wants to integrate the long-contested region, but ethnic Armenians say they fear they will be persecuted and have accused the world of abandoning them.

;

;Baku envisages an amnesty for Karabakh Armenian fighters who give up their arms although some have vowed to continue their resistance, Hikmet Hajiyev, foreign policy adviser to Azerbaijan's president, told Reuters.

;

;"Even with regard to former... combatants... we are envisaging an amnesty or alluding to an amnesty," he said.

;

;But Karabakh Armenians, who call their territory the Republic of Artsakh, said agreement had not yet been reached.

;

;"These questions must still be resolved," David Babayan, an adviser to Samvel Shahramanyan, the president of the self-styled republic, told Reuters. "There are no concrete results yet."

;

;However, Babayan said agreement had been reached for a humanitarian convoy to travel from Armenia to Karabakh on Friday via the Lachin corridor, a road crossing Azerbaijani territory.

;

;"The situation is very difficult: the people are hungry, there is no electricity, no fuel - we have many refugees," he said.

;

;Seven Russian peacekeeping vehicles, including large trucks, passed an Armenian checkpoint heading towards Nagorno-Karabakh on Friday, a Reuters reporter at the scene said.

;

;After this week's swift military operation, Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev vowed to guarantee the rights of ethnic Armenians but said his "iron fist" had consigned their idea of an independent Armenian Karabakh to history. He said the region would be turned into a "paradise" as part of Azerbaijan.

;

;His country, supported by Turkey, has military superiority over Karabakh fighters. But it is unclear how many of those fighters are prepared to lay down their arms or what shape any more comprehensive agreement now being discussed is taking.

;

;Armenia and Azerbaijan, which were both part of the Soviet Union, have fought two wars over Karabakh since its 1991 collapse. The region is internationally recognised as part of Azerbaijan but, backed by Armenia, has enjoyed de facto independence for the past three decades.

;

;Given the bloody history between the two countries, many Armenians are fearful about what will happen next.

;

;"Our one and only hope is help from the Russian peacekeepers. The world turned a blind eye, it doesn't want to hear anything. We think if there are no peacekeepers even for one hour, we will have genocide," said Grigor Zakharyan, an Armenian living near the border with Azerbaijan.

;

;Azerbaijan's claim of victory over the region ushers in yet another twist to the tumultuous history of mountainous Nagorno-Karabakh, which over the centuries has come under the sway of Persians, Turks, Russians, Ottomans and Soviets.

;

;It could also change the delicate balance of power in the South Caucasus, a region criss-crossed by ;oil and gas pipelines; where Russia, the United States, Turkey and Iran are jostling for influence.

;

;Azerbaijani presidential foreign policy adviser Hajiyev said Karabakh Armenian rights would be respected as part of their integration into Azerbaijan. Three cargos of humanitarian help would be delivered to the region on Friday, he said.

;

;Hajiyev said some Karabakh army groups and officers had pledged to continue resistance. "Of course this will cause certain challenges and difficulties but not on a such a big scale," he said.

;

;Armenia's Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan, who has faced protests in Yerevan calling for him to resign over Karabakh, said the government had prepared space for a possible flow of displaced people into Armenia but that it did not want to depopulate Karabakh.

;

;"We must do everything... so that our compatriots, residents of Nagorno-Karabakh have the opportunity to live in their homes without fear, safely and with dignity," he said.

;

;Russia, which has just under 2,000 peacekeepers in Karabakh, has called for calm but has been accused by some Armenians including Pashinyan of not doing enough to support Armenia.

;

;In a video posted on social media, two men were shown throwing red paint at the Russian embassy in Yerevan.

;

;Thousands of Karabakh Armenians were still massed at the local airport where some Russian peacekeepers are based, according to pictures posted on social media.

;

;"We need to see a commitment from the international community, not its indifference," said Ruben Vardanyan, a former state minister of the breakaway government.

;

;Babayan said there was no large-scale movement of people yet as the area was effectively under siege.

;Treasury prices and a gauge of global equities rebounded on Friday after sharp sell-offs earlier this week following the US Federal Reserve's warning that rates will stay higher, a message many in the market find at odds with its soft landing forecast.

;

;Fed policymakers raised the US central bank's forecast for its overnight lending rate by 50 basis points to 5.1% in 2024, but also lifted its outlook for economic growth. Yet higher rates typically crimp bank loans and raise the cost of credit.

;

;"Keeping rates at this level or slightly above this level for an extended period of time, none of that lines up," said Marvin Loh, senior global macro strategist at State Street in Boston.

;

;"Certainly they wanted send the message that higher is going to be around for longer and they went all-in on the soft landing. There's some inconsistencies associated with that."

;

;MSCI's US-centric gauge of global equity performance and stocks on Wall Street bounced back while the dollar and Treasury yields, which move inversely to price, retreated. The benchmark 10-year note eased from 16-year highs of more than 4.5%.

;

;The two-year Treasury yield, which reflects interest rate expectations, fell 3.6 basis points to 5.112%.

;

;In a sign of slowing growth, a ;flash reading; of S&P Global's US Composite PMI index showed US business activity basically at a stand still in September, with the vast services sector essentially idling at the slowest pace since February.

;

;The initial reassessment of the Fed's higher-for-longer policy drove the rise in Treasury yields and created headwinds for risk assets, including equities, credit and emerging markets, but supported the dollar.

;

;MSCI's all-world country index for stocks ;(.MIWD00000PUS); gained 0.37%, but the pan-European STOXX 600 index ;(.STOXX); fell 0.39%.

;

;On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average ;(.DJI); rose 0.17%, the S&P 500 ;(.SPX); gained 0.53% and the Nasdaq Composite ;(.IXIC); added 0.83%.

;

;In currency markets, the dollar pared gains against a basket of currencies after the flash PMI, but remained 0.10% higher at 105.48.

;

;The yen traded at 148.155 to the dollar after falling sharply earlier following the ;Bank of Japan's; decision to hold interest rates in negative territory, suggesting it was in no rush to phase out its massive stimulus program.

;

;Oil prices rose as renewed global supply concerns from Russia's fuel export ban countered demand fears driven by macroeconomic headwinds and higher interest rates.

;

;US crude futures CLc1> rose 0.79% to $90.34 per barrel and Brent was at $93.77, up 0.5% on the day.

;

;In sharp contrast with the US economy, the ;euro zone economy; will likely contract in the third quarter and won't return to growth anytime soon, HCOB's flash purchasing managers' index showed, hitting the euro and yields.

;

;MSCI's index of Asia-Pacific shares ex-Japan ;(.MIAPJ0000PUS); touched a 10-month low before bouncing to trade up 0.9% on vows in China to support private business. It is down 2.8% this week.

;

;Japan's Nikkei ;(.N225); pared losses of as deep as 1% to trade 0.5% lower.

;

;Ten-year Japanese government bond futures rallied though cash yields were little changed and near decade highs at 0.745%.

;

;Central banks in ;Sweden; and ;Norway; announced 25 bp hikes with the prospect of more to come.

;

;Yet the ;Bank of England;, in a split decision, left rates on hold for the first time in nearly two years, sending sterling to a six-month low, while the Swiss franc fell sharply after a surprise hold on rates from the Swiss National Bank.

;

;"It's a lot of mixed messages and stories, and often you get those around turning points," said Craig Ebert, senior economist at BNZ in Wellington.

;

;In emerging markets, Indian bonds and the rupee rallied after ;JPMorgan; said it would add Indian debt to its widely tracked ;emerging markets index;, setting the stage for billions of dollars in foreign inflows.

;

;Gold prices edged higher, helped by a slight pullback in the dollar and bond yields as investors mulled the Fed's hawkish stance and waited for comments from policymakers for clues on the rate outlook.

;Spot gold rose 0.3% to $1,924.60 per ounce, following three sessions of losses.

;But in the first public comments since the central bank this week agreed to hold its benchmark rate steady in a range of from 5.25% to 5.50%, the emphasis was on the possibility that rates may still rise, and on the fact that monetary policy will likely remain tight longer than previously expected.

;

;

;A potential further rise in energy prices, she noted, was a particular risk she was monitoring.

;

;In separate remarks to the Maine Bankers Association, Boston Fed President Susan Collins said a further tightening of monetary policy "is certainly not off the table," though she also counseled "patience" as the Fed tries to get the right signal from sometimes noisy inflation data.

;"I expect rates may have to stay higher, and for longer, than previous projections had suggested," said Collins.

;

;San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly and Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari are scheduled to make remarks later on Friday as the Fed's "blackout" period on post-meeting policy comments lifted.

;

;The ;central bank's decision; to hold its benchmark overnight interest rate steady this week was unanimous.

;

;Bowman said she supported it because of "mixed data" that alongside signs of continued "solid" economic growth also included some decline in inflation and evidence of slowing job growth. Collins does not currently have a vote on rate policy under a Fed system that rotates votes among the 12 reserve bank presidents year by year.

;

;New projections issued at the end of a two-day policy meeting on Wednesday showed 12 of 19 Fed officials expect one additional quarter point rate increase this year. The Fed has two scheduled sessions left in 2023, concluding on Nov. 1 and Dec. 13.

;

;More notably, officials projected that while they still expect to begin reducing interest rates next year as inflation falls, the path down will be slower than previously anticipated.

;

;Though opinions are diffuse, policymakers at the median now see only a half percentage point of rate cuts in 2024 versus the full percentage point decline seen in their June quarterly outlook.
